head.headtext: Similar transactions, other acts and prior difficulties

para.paratext: Evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts shall not be admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show action in conformity therewith. It may, however, be admissible for other purposes, including, but not limited to, proof of motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, or absence of a mistake or accident.[1] The new Code does away with the “bent of mind” and “course of conduct” exceptions that allowed evidence of similar transactions to be presented against a criminal defendant.

The prosecution must provide reasonable notice to the defense in advance of trial to introduce such evidence; however, the notice is not required when the evidence of prior crimes, wrongs or acts is offered to prove the circumstances immediately surrounding the charged crime, motive or prior difficulties between the accused and the alleged victim. The trial court must hold a hearing and may receive evidence outside the presence of the jury to determine whether or not to admit evidence of similar transactions. The burden of proving that the evidence of similar transactions or occurrences should be admitted belongs to the prosecution.[2]

Similar transaction evidence is admissible where the state proves that (1) the evidence is relevant to an issue other than the defendant's character; (2) sufficient evidence shows that the accused actually committed the independent offense; (3) a sufficient connection or similarity exists between the independent offense and the crime charged so the proof of the former tends to prove the latter; and (4) the probative value of the prior offense is not substantially outweighed by the danger of undue prejudice.[3] The proper focus for the court is not the difference between the transactions, but rather the similarities.[4] Moreover, the admissibility of evidence under O.C.G.A. § 24-4-404(b) deals with other crimes, wrongs, or acts extrinsic or independent to the charged offense.[5] Thus, to determine whether the evidence is relevant, the Court must examine O.C.G.A. § 24-4-401, which defines relevant evidence, and then, the Court must examine O.C.G.A. § 24-4-403 which governs which evidence should be excluded because its probative value is outweighed by its prejudice. Kirby v. State, 304 Ga. 472, 819 S.E.2d 468 (2018).

Evidence that defendant had previously exposed her son to dangerous prescription medication was allowed to show the nature of the relationship between the defendant and the victim.[6] Evidence tending to show motive, especially in a trial for murder, is always relevant and admissible, even though it may incidentally place the defendant's character in evidence, and such evidence does not necessitate a hearing under USCR 31.1.[7] Where three witnesses testified that on three different occasions the defendant choked, raped and sodomized them within two years of the crimes charged of malice murder, rape, aggravated sodomy and aggravated assault, evidence of similar transactions was admissible to prove motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan and knowledge.[8]

Similar transactions are admissible to show intent where the defendant has entered a plea of not guilty.[9] Likewise, evidence of a prior crime, when admitted for the purpose of proving motive, may be admissible, even if it is not entirely similar to the charged offense.[10]

The improper admission of similar transactions by the trial court must produce harm to justify a reversal.[11] The trial court will not be reversed on appeal unless its decision to admit similar transaction evidence is clearly erroneous.[12]

App. 758, 780 S.E.2d 426 (2015), the court reversed a conviction where evidence of a defendant's prior conviction was allowed by the trial court as impeachment evidence where the witness testified that she knew about the prior convictions, but she still believed defendant was truthful.
